section.title: Basic Controls
section.para: After instalation &SYSTEM_CONFIG_KDUMP_TOOL; is kdump disabled. And you cannot change any settings.
To enable kdump click on Enable button or OptionsEnable
To disable kdump click on Disable button or OptionsDisable
Apply button is sensitive only if you change any settings. When you click on Apply your settings will be saved. Apply is also in menu FileApply
At any time, you can click on Reload. This will revert any changes you made. This is also in menu FileRevert
Button Help or menu item HelpHelp will show help - which are you now reading.

When kdump is enabled, you can set it up. You have four tabs for settings.
In you can set up basic settings of kdump. Amount of kdump memory.
In you can set up target settings of kdump. You can save kernel dump to local disk and chosen directory. Or send it via SSH or NFS to server
In you can set up filternig level of kdump.
In you can choose kernel, set up its command line arguments, you can choose default action and confgure core collector.
Much more settings can be done by hand in your bootloader configuration file (/etc/grub.conf), in kdump configuration file (/etc/kdump.conf). For more information read /etc/kdump.conf.

section.title: Basic Settings
section.para:
In Basic Settings you can see these items:
Total System Memory — Shows allover memory in your system.
Current kdump Memory — Shows actual memory reserved for kdump.
New kdump Memory — Shows new memory you wish to reserve for kdump. Beside is spin button allowing you to change this amount.
Usable Memory — Shows usable memory of system after applying your changes.

section.title: Local filesystem
section.para: In order to save vmcore file to local directory, choose Local filesystem.
You can enter path to your directory by hand in path entry. Next to this entry is File chooser button, which allows you to browse your directory tree and choose it.
Also you can specify/choose partition in Partition combo box.

section.title: Raw device
section.para: Here you can select device where will be vmcore saved. The vmcore will be saved in raw data. This will dd /proc/vmcore into partition.

section.title: Network
section.para: You are allowed to save vmcore to NFS mount and/or send it to server via SSH.

listitem.para: NFS — Will mount fs, specified by Server name, and copy /proc/vmcore to /var/crash/%HOST-%DATE/, supports DNS.
SSH — Will scp /proc/vmcore to user@server:/var/crash/%HOST-%DATE/, supports DNS
NOTE: make sure user has necessary write permissions on server

section.title: Expert Settings
section.para: Expert Settings is used to fine settings.
You can select kernel in Capture kernel selection, on which you would like to set kdump. In combo box should be listed all available kernels.
In Command line options section you can edit command line arguments for selected kernel. At any time you can revert changes by pressing Refresh button

There are 4 default actions that you can select in Default action section:
Mount rootfs and run /sbin/init — This is default action.
Reboot — simply reboot the system and loose the core that you are trying to retrieve.
Halt — simply halt the system after attempting to capture a vmcore, regardless of success or failure.
Shell — drop to an msh session inside the initramfs from where you can try to record the core manually. Exiting this shell reboots the system.
In Core collector you can specify core collector command. It should begin with makedumpfile.
